video.title: TEDTalks: Building Wonder
video.synopsis: Sharing their ingenious work, architectural experts from across the globe reflect on historical spaces and the future of building design.

episodes.synopsis: Danish architect Bjarke Ingels rockets through his eco-flashy designs that look and act like nature.
episodes.title: Bjarke Ingels: Three Warp-Speed Architecture Tales

episodes.synopsis: Architect Thomas Heatherwick shows five projects featuring ingenious bio-inspired designs.
episodes.title: Thomas Heatherwick: Building the Seed Cathedral

episodes.synopsis: What would buildings and products look like if designers took into account "all children, all species, for all time"?
episodes.title: William McDonough on Cradle to Cradle Design

episodes.synopsis: 2006 TED Prize winner Cameron Sinclair demonstrates how designers and architects can respond to the world's housing crises.
episodes.title: Cameron Sinclair on Open-Source Architecture

episodes.synopsis: Architect Joshua Prince-Ramus takes the audience on dazzling, dizzying virtual tours of three recent projects.
episodes.title: Joshua Prince-Ramus on Seattle's Library

episodes.synopsis: Architect Liz Diller of DS+R shares her firm's more unusual work, including the Blur Building, whose walls are made of fog.
episodes.title: Liz Diller Plays with Architecture

episodes.synopsis: Alex Steffen shows projects that expand our access to things we want and need -- while reducing the time we spend in cars.
episodes.title: Alex Steffen: The Shareable Future of Cities

episodes.synopsis: What is the purpose of a public space? James Howard Kunstler aruges America is a nation of places not worth caring about.
episodes.title: James H. Kunstler Dissects Suburbia

episodes.synopsis: Kamal Meattle shows how an arrangement of three common houseplants can result in measurably cleaner indoor air.
episodes.title: Kamal Meattle on How to Grow Fresh Air

episodes.synopsis: Jane Poynter explores sustaining life in the harshest of environments after living two years and 20 minutes in Biosphere 2.
episodes.title: Jane Poynter: Life in Biosphere 2

episodes.synopsis: Amazing engineering feats built centuries ago are still used today -- and are often superior to modern water megaprojects.
episodes.title: Anupam Mishra: The Ancient Ingenuity of Water Harvesting

episodes.synopsis: Mitchell Joachim shares a vision for sustainable, organic architecture: abodes grown from plants and -- wait for it -- meat.
episodes.title: Mitchell Joachim: Don't Build Your Home, Grow It!

episodes.synopsis: Venice, Italy, is sinking. To save it, Rachel Armstrong explains we need to make architecture grow itself instead of using inert materials.
episodes.title: Rachel Armstrong: Architecture That Repairs Itself?

episodes.synopsis: Joshua Prince-Ramus shows his re-creation of a theater that reconfigures itself at the touch of a button.
episodes.title: Joshua Prince-Ramus: Building a Theater That Remakes Itself

episodes.synopsis: Magnus Larsson details his bold plan to transform the Sahara Desert using bacteria and the sand itself.
episodes.title: Magnus Larsson: Turning Dunes into Architecture

episodes.synopsis: Michael Pawlyn describes three habits of nature that could transform architecture and society.
episodes.title: Michael Pawlyn: Using Nature's Genius in Architecture

episodes.synopsis: Ellen Dunham-Jones fires the starting shot for the next big sustainable design project: retrofitting suburbia.
episodes.title: Ellen Dunham-Jones: Retrofitting Suburbia
